samples.question: So could you describe an interesting neighbor?
samples.transcript: Okay, I would say, the most interesting neighbor I had was the neighbor I actually had while I was growing up. So, I lived in one house for 10 years and during that time, there was a neighbor and it was basically a family, but I would describe most of the parent. so this parent was very extravagant. I would see this parent or this neighbor, always coming in and out of the way. They came out of their house in the best dressed like suit. but one day actually their house burned down and it was like a huge thing like all across the news in our neighborhood, in our neighborhood. And basically, fortunately nobody was hurt. But since the house burned down, they had to rebuild their house and they took this opportunity to build this grand mansion in this tiny suburban neighborhood. it is this huge mansion with a huge fountain in front of their yard. And I was like, wow, quite an interesting person. Quite, showy and kind of extravagant. and yeah, that is what I say.
samples.transcript_original: Okay, um, I would say, uh, the most interesting neighbor I had was the neighbor I actually had while I was growing up. So, I lived in one house for 10 years and during that time, um, there was a neighbor and it was basically a family, but I would describe most of the parent. Um, so this parent was very extravagant. Um, I would see this parent or this neighbor, um, always coming in and out of the way. They came out of their house in the best dressed like suit. Um, but one day actually their house burned down and it was like a huge thing like all across the news in our neighborhood, in our neighborhood. And basically, um, uh, fortunately nobody was hurt. But since the house burned down, they had to rebuild their house and they took this opportunity to build this grand mansion in this tiny suburban neighborhood. It's this huge mansion with a huge fountain in front of their yard. And I was like, wow, quite an interesting person. Quite, um, showy and kind of extravagant. Um, and yeah, that's what I say.

So, I lived in one house for 10 years and during that time, there was a neighbor and it was basically a family, but I would describe most of the parent. so this parent was very extravagant. I would see this parent or this neighbor, always coming in and out of the way. They came out of their house in the best dressed like suit. but one day actually their house burned down and it was like a huge thing like all across the news in our neighborhood, in our neighborhood. And basically, fortunately nobody was hurt. But since the house burned down, they had to rebuild their house and they took this opportunity to build this grand mansion in this tiny suburban neighborhood. it is this huge mansion with a huge fountain in front of their yard. And I was like, wow, quite an interesting person. Quite, showy and kind of extravagant. and yeah, that is what I say.

samples.question: Why do you think that is?
samples.transcript: I feel like in today's society, a lot of people are more wary of strangers, even if it is their neighbors.. people are not willing to be, like, going out of their way to be nice to someone, to get to know somebody. especially since there is like a lot of crime and violences and stories about people getting hurt from either neighbors and stuff like that. Yes, indeed.
samples.transcript_original: Um, I feel like in today's society, um, a lot of people are more wary of strangers, even if it's their neighbors. Mm. Um, people aren't willing to be, um, like, going out of their way to be nice to someone, to get to know somebody. Um, especially since there's like a lot of crime and violences and stories about people getting hurt from either neighbors and stuff like that. Yes, indeed.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I feel like in today's society, a lot of people are more wary of strangers, even if it is their neighbors.. people are not willing to be, like, going out of their way to be nice to someone, to get to know somebody. especially since there is like a lot of crime and violences and stories about people getting hurt from either neighbors and stuff like that. Yes, indeed.

samples.question: And do you think in the countryside it is the same or it is a little bit different?
samples.transcript: Definitely same. In the countryside it is a little bit more different. like thinking about like people who live in farms and who tend to be a lot more farther away, people would be going out of their way to, you know, greet, greet their neighbors and introduce themselves. because, you know, since they are so isolated, they want that human interaction. They want to get to know people. And then in that way, they can help each other whenever something happens and, just always be there for each other. Okay.
samples.transcript_original: Definitely same. In the countryside it's a little bit more different. Uh, because, you know, since they're so isolated, they want that human interaction. They want to get to know people. And then in that way, they can help each other whenever something happens and, um, just always be there for each other. Okay.

They want to get to know people. And then in that way, they can help each other whenever something happens and, just always be there for each other.

samples.question: And how can people improve their relationship with neighbors if they would like to?
samples.transcript: I would definitely say that first of all, you know, greeting and then once you move into a new place, I would definitely go around the neighborhood and like pass around like cookies or give them some gifts and just introduce them and say, oh, like I am the new tenant or new homeowner.
samples.transcript_original: Um, I would definitely say that first of all, you know, greeting and then once you move into a new place, I would definitely go around the neighborhood and um, like pass around like cookies or give them some gifts and just introduce them and say, oh, like um, I'm the new tenant or new um, homeowner.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I would definitely say that first of all, you know, greeting and then once you move into a new place, I would definitely go around the neighborhood and like pass around like cookies or give them some gifts and just introduce them and say, oh, like I am the new tenant or new homeowner.

samples.question: Like whenever I need help, can you like please help?
samples.transcript: I will always be there to help you and stuff like that.
samples.transcript_original: I'll always be there to help you and stuff like that.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I will always be there to help you and stuff like that.

samples.question: And how do you think people would react to that these days?
samples.transcript: These days, I would definitely say people would be shocked at first. they would be like, oh, okay. kind of like, oh, like you are a stranger. I do not know you. But once they get to warm up to that person, definitely feel like it is a relationship that can definitely establish. yes.

But once they get to warm up to that person, definitely feel like it's a relationship that can definitely establish. Mm, yes.

But once they get to warm up to that person, definitely feel like it is a relationship that can definitely establish.

samples.question: And how do children build relationships with other children in their neighborhood?
samples.transcript: I feel like it is such a simple way for children to build relationships.
samples.transcript_original: Um, I feel like it's such a simple way for children to build relationships.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I feel like it is such a simple way for children to build relationships.

samples.question: Do you want to hang out?
samples.transcript: Let us go to the playground and play tag. samples.question: And why do you think it is more difficult for adults to do the same thing?
samples.transcript: For adults, I would definitely say it is a, societal and social, there is an aspect to it. first, adults you have to be like, like I would say you have that societal or social pressure that you have to act a certain way. And so adults tend to be a little bit more careful, in a sense, when they are meeting neighbors and they want to, since they are the adults and they have to take care of their family, especially in a neighborhood, I would say it is a little bit more difficult for them to establish a relationship. Indeed.
samples.transcript_original: For adults, I would definitely say it's a, um, societal and social, uh, there's an aspect to it. samples.question: And what do you think are some common problems between neighbors?
samples.transcript: Common problems between neighbors definitely would say if you are living in an apartment and you have a first, if you have a floor above you and below you, you are going to hear a lot of, sound. So there is a lot of, like, I would not say noise pollution, but a lot of sound, like if the upstairs neighbors stomping or playing loud music, that would definitely be, like, a big factor where neighbors tend to fight And dislike each other. Or sometimes things are placed in front of your door, but it is like garbage or trash. And so people like tend to fight over things. I am like, you suspect that, oh, I think that neighbor put that trash in front of my door. and you start fighting with them. And then you leave sticky notes, writing passive aggressive, messages to each other. So I would definitely say it is just tiny little things that really bother a neighbor. Okay, perfect. That will do.

That will do.

samples.question: What is your first name, please?
samples.transcript: Saskia. Thanks Saskia. At the beginning of the IELTS test, you will be required to provide an ID, but as this is a practice test, we do not need to do that today. I want to begin by talking about you.

samples.question: Do you have a large family?
samples.transcript: I do not actually, it is just myself and my brother, so it is very tight knit.
samples.transcript_original: I don't actually, it's just myself and my brother, so it's very tight knit.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I do not actually, it is just myself and my brother, so it is very tight knit.

samples.question: And how often do you speak to your family?
samples.transcript: Every day I make sure to call my parents, both my mum and my dad at least once a day, and my brother and I are very close, so I am actually going over to see him. because of the distance, I make it a point to, you know, call them every day so we do not feel such a large gap.

samples.question: What do you think about the language?

Now I want to talk about the sky.

samples.question: And do you enjoy learning about the stars and planets?
samples.transcript: I do. I, I think it is very interesting how the stars and the planets really influence how people perceive their lives. I am not saying that they actually influence your life, but I am saying how, you know, I feel like people always want something to blame when things go wrong. And the stars have been a very good scapegoat for them. The stars have been a very good scapegoat for them. To be a scapegoat for something. Lovely, lovely language. She speaks really naturally. She is talking as though she is talking to a friend. She is sitting back in her chair. She is looking directly at the examiner. Great body language. It will not help you in your test but it might make you feel a little bit more relaxed and confident in yourself. Good job. I am going to give you a topic and I would like you to talk about it for one to two minutes.
